tutorial.title: Coffee shop menu - Part 1
tutorial.descriptionContent: Dive into the world of a bustling coffee shop, where you'll craft a detailed and engaging menu. This isn't just about listing espressos and lattes; it's about structuring information in a rich and organized way.

executableContent.instructions:
Welcome to the **Coffee Shop** project! Here, you'll build and style a drinks and snacks menu for a local coffee shop.

Let's start with the base HTML structure.

1. Create a `doctype` element, followed by an `html` element underneath.
2. Inside the `html` element, add the `head` and `body` elements.
3. Inside the `head` element, add a `title` element with the text `Coffee Shop Menu`. This will be the page's title, visible in a browser tab.

With the title and the base webpage structure in place, let's add some elements that will actually show up on our webpage, starting with the name of the cafe and a menu description.

1. Inside the `body`, add a first-level heading element for the cafe name. Give it the text `Bean & Brew Cafe`.
2. Also inside the `body`, but under the heading you've just created, add a paragraph with some text like `Discover our selection of drinks and snacks.`
3. Finally, we'll want to style these two elements using similar rules, so create a `div` element and nest both of them inside it.

Now that we have some text, it's time to set up the stylesheet! For that, we'll link the stylesheet.

1. Inside the `head`, link the stylesheet `style.css`. That's where we'll write the style rules for our menu page.

Time to set classes to the elements we want to style since just using element names is too unspecific.

1. We want to use a class selector to style the heading and paragraph together, so set the class `header` to the `div` element.

executableContent.instructions:
With the stylesheet and the class in place, let's create a rule in our stylesheet. We'll want to set a background, style the font, and find a suitable text placement.

1. Create an empty rule that targets the header class.
2. Inside this rule, add an attribute to align the text centrally.
3. Set the text color to a coffee shade using this color hex code `#5A2D0C`.
4. To balance the dark text, set the background to a pastel orange using `#FFEBCD`.
5. Add more space around the text with a `20px` padding.
6. Finally, make all the text bold.

executableContent.instructions:
We've styled the first part of the menu, but now we need to show some menu items. We'll use a list for that. 1. Under the `div`, create an unordered list. 2. Inside the unordered list, add six list items. Feel free to add your personal favorites or use the following list: ```HTML
  • Espresso
  • Cappuccino
  • Latte
  • Croissant
  • Blueberry Muffin
  • Matcha Cookie
    • ```

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add a touch of style to the menu list as well. We'll give it a background color and add some space around the text.

1. Before styling, give the unordered list a `menu-list` class, so that we can use this selector when building the CSS rule.
2. Move on to the `style.css` tab and create an empty rule that targets the `menu-list` class.
3. Give it a pastel lavender background color using the following hex code: `#E6E6FA`.
4. Add some space around the text with a `20px` padding.
